unnormalised: Someone asked me about understanding probability and stats, especially with the kind of data crunching we see these days. It's actually simpler than it looks! Think of tossing a coin. P(Heads) = 1/2. That's probability right there. Statistics builds on this, helping us make sense of loads of such events. Like figuring out the avg salary of engineers in Bangalore based on, say, 1000 data points. Or predicting election outcomes using polls.

unnormalised: Now, formulas like standard deviation (σ) and the normal distribution curve (bell curve) might seem scary. But they just describe how data is spread out. Imagine plotting the heights of all students in your class. You'd probably see most clustered around a certain height, with fewer very tall or short kids. The normal distribution helps us model that. Concepts like Bayes' Theorem – P(A|B) – are super useful in machine learning too. Even simple percentages can be powerful – if 75% of your sample group prefers brand A, it's a strong indicator!
